statement.p:
The quadratic approximation of a function f(x) about x=3 is
f(x) \approx -x^2+6x
What are the values of f(3), f'(3), f''(3), and f'''(3)?

hint.p: If Q(x) is the quadratic approximation of f about 3, then Q(3)=f(3), Q'(3)=f'(3), and Q''(3)=f''(3).

answer.p: f(3)=9, f'(3)=0, f''(3)=-2; there is not enough information to know f'''(3).

solution.p:
If Q(x) is the quadratic approximation of f about 3, then Q(3)=f(3), Q'(3)=f'(3), and Q''(3)=f''(3). There is no guarantee that f(x) and Q(x) share the same third derivative, though, so we do not have enough information to know f'''(3).
f(3)&=-3^2+6(3)=9
f'(3)&=\left.\diff{}{x}\left\{-x^2+6x\right\}\right|_{x=3}=\left.-2x+6\right|_{x=3}=0
f''(3)&=\left.\ddiff{2}{}{x}\left\{-x^2+6x\right\}\right|_{x=3}= \left.\diff{}{x}\left\{-2x+6\right\}\right|_{x=3}=-2

statement.p: Give a quadratic approximation of f(x)=2x+5 about x=a.

hint.p: It is a very good approximation.

solution.p:
The quadratic approximation of f(x) about x=a is
f(x) &\approx f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{1}{2}f''(a)(x-a)^2
We subsitute f(a)=2a+5, f'(a)=2, and f''(a)=0: f(x) &\approx (2a+5)+2(x-a)=2x+5
So, our approximation is f(x) \approx 2x+5.
Remark: Our approximation is exact for every value of x. This will always happen with a quadratic approximation of a function that is quadratic, linear, or constant.

statement.p: Use a quadratic approximation to estimate \log(0.93).
(Remember that in CLP-1 we use \log x to mean the natural logarithm of x, \log_e x.)

solution.p:
We approximate the function f(x)=\log x about the point x=1. We choose 1 because it is close to 0.93, and we can evaluate f(x) and its first two derivatives at x=1.
f(1)&=0
f'(x)&=\frac{1}{x}\qquad \Rightarrow \qquad f'(1)=1
f''(x)&=\frac{-1}{x^2} \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad f''(1)=-1
So, f(x) &\approx f(1)+f'(1)(x-1)+\frac{1}{2}f''(1)(x-1)^2
&=0+(x-1)-\frac{1}{2}(x-1)^2
When x=0.93:
f(0.93) &\approx (0.93-1)-\frac{1}{2}(0.93-1)^2=-0.07-\frac{1}{2}(0.0049)
\amp=-0.07245
Remark: a calculator approximates \log(0.93) \approx -0.07257. We're pretty close.

statement.p: Use a quadratic approximation to estimate \cos\left(\dfrac{1}{15}\right).

hint.p: You'll probably want to centre your approximation about x=0.

solution.p:
We approximate the function f(x)=\cos x. We can easily evaluate \cos x and \sin x (\sin x will appear in the first derivative) at x=0, and 0 is quite close to \dfrac{1}{15}, so we centre our approximation about x=0.
f(0)&=1
f'(x)&=-\sin x
f'(0)&=-\sin(0)=0
f''(x)&=-\cos x
f''(0)&=-\cos(0)=-1
Using the quadratic approximation f(x) \approx f(0)+f'(0)(x-0)+\frac{1}{2}f''(0)(x-0)^2: f(x)&\approx 1 -\frac{1}{2}x^2
f\left(\frac{1}{15}\right)&\approx 1-\frac{1}{2\cdot 15^2}=\frac{449}{450}
We approximate \cos\left(\dfrac{1}{15}\right)\approx\dfrac{449}{450} .
Remark: \dfrac{449}{450}= 0.99\overline{77}, while a calculator gives \cos\left(\frac{1}{15}\right )\approx 0.9977786. Our approximation has an error of about 0.000001.

statement.p: Calculate the quadratic approximation of f(x)=e^{2x} about x=0.

hint.p:
The quadratic approximation of a function f(x) about x=a is
f(x) \approx f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{1}{2}f''(a)(x-a)^2

solution.p:
The quadratic approximation of a function f(x) about x=a is
f(x) &\approx f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{1}{2}f''(a)(x-a)^2
We compute derivatives. f(0)&=e^0=1
f'(x)&=2e^{2x}
f'(0)&=2e^0=2
f''(x)&=4e^{2x}
f''(0)&=4e^0=4
Substituting: f(x) &\approx 1+2(x-0)+\frac{4}{2}(x-0)^2 f(x) &\approx 1+2x+2x^2

statement.p: Use a quadratic approximation to estimate 5^{\tfrac{4}{3}}.

hint.p: One way to go about this is to approximate the function f(x) = 5 \cdot x^{1/3} , because then 5^{4/3} = 5 \cdot 5^{1/3} =f(5).

solution.p: Remark: \dfrac{275}{32} = 8.59375, and a calculator gives 5^{4/3}\approx 8.5499. Although 5 and 8 are somewhat far apart, our estimate is only off by about 0.04.

li.p: [] For every value of n, the term being added is simply the constant 1. So, \ds\sum_{n=5}^{30} 1 = 1+1+\cdots+1. The trick is figuring out how many 1s are added. Our index n takes on all integers from 5 to 30, including 5 and 30, which is 26 numbers. So, \ds\sum_{n=5}^{30}=26.

If you're having a hard time seeing why the sum is 26, instead of 25, think of it this way: there are thirty numbers in the collection \{1,2,3,4,5,6,\ldots,29,30\}. If we remove the first four, we get 30-4=26 numbers in the collection \{5,6,\ldots,30\}.

hint.p: To get an alternating sign, consider powers of (-1).

solution.p:
For each of these, there are many solutions. We provide some below.
1+2+3+4+5 = \ds\sum_{n=1}^5n
2+4+6+8=\ds\sum_{n=1}^4 2n
3+5+7+9+11=\ds\sum_{n=1}^{5}(2n+1)
9+16+25+36+49=\ds\sum_{n=3}^7 n^2
9+4+16+5+25+6+36+7+49+8=\ds\sum_{n=3}^7 (n^2+n+1)
8+15+24+35+48= \ds\sum_{n=3}^7 (n^2-1)
3-6+9-12+15-18=\ds\sum_{n=1}^6 (-1)^{n+1}3n
Remark: if we had written (-1)^n instead of (-1)^{n+1}, with everything else the same, the signs would have been reversed.

statement.p: Use a quadratic approximation of f(x)=2\arcsin x about x=0 to approximate f(1). What number are you approximating?

hint.p: You can evaluate f(1) exactly. Recall \ds\diff{}{x}\arcsin x = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}.

solution.p:
Let's start by taking the first two derivative of f(x).
f(x)&=2\arcsin x&&\Rightarrow& f(0)&=2(0)=0
f'(x)&=\frac{2}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}&&\Rightarrow& f'(0)&=\frac{2}{1}=2
f''(x)&=\diff{}{x}\left\{2(1-x^2)^{-\tfrac{1}{2}}\right\}
&=2\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\right)(1-x^2)^{-\tfrac{3}{2}}(-2x) \amp\amp\amp\amp\mbox{(chain rule)}
&=\frac{2x}{\left(\sqrt{1-x^2}\right)^3}&&\Rightarrow& f''(0)&=0
Now, we can find the quadratic approximation about x=0. f(x)&\approx f(0)+f'(0)x+\frac{1}{2}f''(0)x^2
&=2x
f(1)& \approx 2
Our quadratic approximation gives 2\arcsin(1) \approx 2. However, 2\arcsin(1) is exactly equal to 2\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)=\pi. We've just made the rather unfortunate approximation \pi \approx 2.

statement.p: Use a quadratic approximation of e^x to estimate e as a decimal.

hint.p: Let f(x)=e^x, and use the quadratic approximation of f(x) about x=0 (given in your text, or you can reproduce it) to approximate f(1).

solution.p:
From the text, the quadratic approximation of e^x about x=0 is
e^x \approx 1+x+\frac{1}{2}x^2
